Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Spectral Diagnostics of Heavy Elements At High Redshift
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-1109061/1108830
Ferland/Kulkarni

Heavy elements are produced by stellar evolution and then distributed into interstellar space. Understanding the enrichment history of galaxies is therefore crucial to understanding the star formation and feedback processes that are central to galaxy evolution. Absorption lines of damped Lyman-alpha (DLA) and sub-DLA absorbers in the spectra of background quasars or gamma-ray burst afterglows provide the most sensitive tools to measure the heavy element content of distant galaxies. High-resolution spectroscopy has revealed some interesting puzzles, especially relating to variations in metallicities and enrichment. Current and proposed large telescopes will greatly expand the observational database, especially at high redshift, but unfortunately essential atomic data - both oscillator strengths and recombination coefficients - are highly uncertain or unknown for most elements beyond Magnesium in the periodic table. These gaps in the existing atomic database are the greatest weakness in deriving abundances from spectra and realizing the scientific potential of the observations. This project will improve that situation by carrying out the following steps: 1) calculate more accurate oscillator strengths for transitions of all relevant ions from Aluminum to Zinc using state-of-the-art quantal codes; 2) calculate dielectronic recombination coefficients for all relevant ions of key elements; 3) incorporate these data into the widely used photoionization code 'Cloudy'; 4) apply the new 'Cloudy' models to existing and new spectral data; and 5) provide feedback to the atomic theory from the observational and modeling results (the last and most crucial step).

This study will help to determine whether the current picture of chemical evolution of galaxies is accurate, while providing a much-needed improvement in atomic data and photoionization modeling. Because the team combines expertise in atomic physics, plasma simulations, and observational spectroscopy, they are uniquely qualified to carry out this work.

The improvements to the widely available modeling tool 'Cloudy' will be of immediate benefit to other areas of astrophysics ranging from star-forming clouds to active galactic nuclei, because that utility is used extensively and cited in over 200 publications each year. The work includes significant educational benefits at both institutions and a strong outreach involvement, and continues a strong international collaboration, to which the junior researchers will be extensively exposed. Due to the make-up of the team, it also enhances the quality and diversity of the scientific workforce in a geographical region with few astronomers, and especially very few minority or women astronomers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Most chemical elements beyond Helium are produced inside the cores of stars or in supernova explosions at the end of the stars’ lives. Thus these heavier elements (loosely called “metals” in astronomy) were absent in the Universe until stars could start forming. One of the fundamental questions in astrophysics is how, starting from zero, the abundances of these elements evolved to reach their current levels. Understanding the evolution of the elements is of great importance even for other areas of human enquiry, such as the formation of planets, and even the emergence of life. One of the most reliable ways of measuring the abundances of the chemical elements in the distant Universe consists of absorption spectroscopy of background sources. However, the inferences drawn from spectroscopy depend on the accuracy of the atomic data used.

Intellectual Merit: This project involved making improvements to some of the atomic data and increasing the measurements of chemical compositions of distant galaxies. The main outcomes were as follows:

1) Calculations of improved atomic data were performed for some of the key ions. The implications of these calculations were calculated for the element abundances in distant galaxies. In some cases, the new atomic data imply corrections of as much as 35% to the element abundances inferred for distant galaxies. Calculations of improved emission spectra were also made using the new atomic data. These calculations are applicable to a wide range of other astrophysical objects.

2) A large compilation of the latest atomic data was made for many key ions commonly measured in astrophysical spectroscopy. This compilation will be very valuable for studies of a wide range of astrophysical objects (e.g., stars, and the gas in and around galaxies).

3) Spectra of a number of distant galaxies were obtained with the goal of increasing the observational data. Surprisingly high element abundances (as much as or more than in our Sun) were detected in a number of absorption-selected galaxies as of 5 or even 10 billion years ago.

4) A very interesting distant, moderately gas-rich galaxy was found to have peculiar element abundances at an epoch corresponding to only 1.2 billion years after the Big Bang. This galaxy is much poorer in heavy elements compared to the expectation from other similarly gas-rich galaxies that are somewhat closer to the Earth. Moreover, these kind of moderately gas-rich absorbers appear to evolve faster than the more gas-rich absorbers, suggesting that these two types of absorbers may be the progenitors of the two main classes of galaxies, i.e., the early-type (e.g. elliptical) galaxies and the late-type (e.g., spiral) galaxies, respectively.

5) Evidence for strong dust depletion and possible non-uniformities (patchiness) in dust was found in a distant moderately gas-rich galaxy as of 1.2 billion years after the Big Bang. This shows that dust in the distant Universe may be different in composition from  the dust in our Milky Way (MW) galaxy or nearby galaxies.

6) For some distant absorbing galaxies, the spatial distribution of metals and the gas kinematics were determined. These data showed flat or weakly negative metallicity gradients with increasing distance from the galaxy centers.

7) Emission lines indicative of star formation were detected in a number of moderately nearby galaxies with background quasars at small angular separations. These galaxies appear to be dusty and dominated by disks, with lower metal abundances than in the Sun.

8) Absorption features from silicate dust were detected, for the first time, in several distant galaxies. These galaxies show stronger silicate features compared to extrapolation from the MW diffuse interstellar medium (ISM), suggesting they have larger dust grains or more O-rich regions producing more silicate dust. Some of the galaxies studied also show potential detections of crystalline silicates (not seen in the MW ISM), perhaps suggesting warmer regions with lower cosmic ray fluxes. Again, these results suggest that the dust in distant galaxies may be different from the dust in the MW and nearby galaxies, contrary to the assumptions made in most past studies.

Evolution in dust properties has significant implications for studies of galaxy evolution, because dust affects many astrophysical processes (e.g., molecule production, star formation), as well as the appearance of galaxies and their properties inferred from observations (e.g., masses, distances). If the dust in distant galaxies differs systematically from the dust in nearby galaxies, this could potentially affect the measurements of cosmic expansion and hence studies of dark energy.

To summarize, this project led to a number of improvements in the measurements of the chemical compositions of distant galaxies and the atomic physics needed for inferring accurate element abundances from the observations.

Broader Impacts consisted of research training of several graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers, including women and/or under-represented minorities. The project team also engaged in a number of outreach activities for local schools and organizations.
